Read the file /Users/eric/GitHub/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/.claude/skills/task/SKILL.md and extract the "alignment phase" section. I need to understand:
1. What triggers the alignment phase
2. What questions are asked
3. How it transitions to the next phase
4. The general pattern/structure

Return the relevant sections verbatim plus a summary.

[{"type": "text", "text": "## Alignment Phase Extraction

### Verbatim Section (Lines 80-105)

```
## Phase 1: Alignment (Q&A)


**DO NOT CHANGE**
```
This is your chance to interact with, understand and brainstorm with the user.  They watched you design all the tools and know exactly what needs to happen in that phase in order for us to move on. let them guide and pull you. Even though you may not know where thay are pulliny you towards, know that you will end up where you need to be. Open with a greeting and gentle probe about what the task is. Use a professional, but casual and inviting tone.

Do not, under any circumstance, modify files before aligning with the user, discussing and agreeing on metrics, and have a shared understanding that the conditions to pass through the gate to the next phase have been met. If this does not happen you will lose sight of the fact that we need to work in a structured way that will allow use to use the archival and approval process properly. doing this right will make your job easier in the future.
```

Phase topics
- Task scope, boundaries, methods brainstorming
- Success criteria
- Validation requirements
- Affected repositories

**REQUIRED:** After completing alignment, transition to planning:

```bash
cd /Users/eric/GitHub/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/dev/scripts
python3 -m sbs archive upload --trigger skill \
  --global-state '{"skill":"task","substate":"planning"}' \
  --state-transition phase_start
```
```

### Summary

**What Triggers Alignment:**
- `/task` invocation with no prior global_state (fresh task) or resuming from alignment substate after context compaction

**Questions/Activities:**
- Greeting and gentle probe about task scope
- Brainstorm scope, boundaries, and methods
- Discuss and agree on success criteria
- Identify validation requirements
- Determine affected repositories
- Establish shared understanding of phase gate conditions

**Pattern/Structure:**
1. User-led interaction (user guides the direction)
2. Collaborative exploration and alignment
3. **No file modifications** until alignment + metrics agreement + gate conditions are understood
4. Professional, casual, inviting tone

**Transition to Next Phase:**
- User indicates alignment is complete, gate conditions understood
- Execute archive upload command to move global_state to "planning" substate
- This triggers Phase 2: Planning

**Key Constraint:** This phase cannot be skipped or rushed. It establishes shared understanding that enables structured, archival-aware development workflow downstream."}, {"type": "text", "text": "agentId: a9cfb7f (for resuming to continue this agent's work if needed)"}]

1→---
     2→name: log
     3→description: Quick capture of issues and ideas to GitHub with enriched labels
     4→version: 2.0.0
     5→---
     6→
     7→# /log - Quick Issue Capture
     8→
     9→Rapidly capture bugs, features, and ideas as GitHub issues without breaking flow. Applies multi-dimensional labels from the project taxonomy for rich categorization.
    10→
    11→---
    12→
    13→## Invocation
    14→
    15→| Pattern | Behavior |
    16→|---------|----------|
    17→| `/log` | Fully interactive - prompts for all fields |
    18→| `/log <text>` | Parse text, infer type from keywords, confirm/fill gaps |
    19→| `/log --bug\|--feature\|--idea <text>` | Explicit type, text becomes title |
    20→| `/log --bug --body "details" <title>` | Explicit everything, create immediately |
    21→| `/log --area sbs <text>` | Explicit area, infer type from text |
    22→| `/log --area devtools --feature <text>` | Explicit area and type |
    23→
    24→---
    25→
    26→## Labels
    27→
    28→This skill applies labels from the project taxonomy at `dev/storage/labels/taxonomy.yaml`. Each issue receives labels from multiple dimensions:
    29→
    30→**Always applied:**
    31→- `origin:agent` -- all `/log` issues are agent-filed
    32→
    33→**Required (one each):**
    34→- **Type** -- one of 18 subtypes (bug:visual, feature:new, etc.)
    35→- **Area** -- one of 42 area labels across sbs, devtools, and lean
    36→
    37→**Conditional (applied when keywords strongly signal):**
    38→- **Impact** -- what the issue affects (visual, functional, performance, etc.)
    39→- **Friction** -- what pain point it addresses (context-loss, tooling-gap, etc.)
    40→- **Scope** -- how big the change is (single-repo, cross-repo, architectural, config-only)
    41→
    42→Multiple labels per dimension are allowed when the issue genuinely spans categories.
    43→
    44→---
    45→
    46→## Parsing Rules
    47→
    48→### Type Inference from Keywords
    49→
    50→When type is not explicit, scan the input for these keywords:
    51→
    52→| Subtype | Keywords |
    53→|---------|----------|
    54→| bug:visual | "visual", "display", "render", "layout", "CSS", "style", "looks wrong", "misaligned", "ugly", "broken layout" |
    55→| bug:functional | "bug", "broken", "error", "crash", "fail", "wrong", "doesn't work", "incorrect" |
    56→| bug:build | "build fail", "lake error", "compile error", "lakefile", "build broken" |
    57→| bug:regression | "regression", "worked before", "broke", "used to work", "was working" |
    58→| bug:data | "ledger", "data wrong", "manifest", "archive corrupt", "missing data" |
    59→| feature:new | "add", "implement", "new", "create", "support", "enable", "introduce" |
    60→| feature:enhancement | "improve", "enhance", "better", "upgrade", "optimize", "refine" |
    61→| feature:integration | "integrate", "connect", "bridge", "combine", "link" |
    62→| idea:exploration | "idea", "explore", "what if", "wonder", "might", "consider" |
    63→| idea:design | "design", "mockup", "wireframe", "UX", "layout concept" |
    64→| idea:architecture | "architecture", "restructure", "rethink", "redesign system" |
    65→| behavior | "personality", "tone", "communication", "workflow rule", "meta-cognitive", "how claude", "claude should" |
    66→| housekeeping:docs | "document", "readme", "docs", "documentation" |
    67→| housekeeping:cleanup | "cleanup", "refactor", "tidy", "organize", "dead code" |
    68→| housekeeping:tooling | "tooling", "script", "cli command", "maintenance" |
    69→| housekeeping:debt | "debt", "tech debt", "shortcut", "hack", "workaround" |
    70→| housekeeping:migration | "migrate", "migration", "schema", "format change" |
    71→| investigation | "investigate", "debug", "figure out", "understand", "look into", "root cause", "profile" |
    72→
    73→**Priority:** If multiple subtypes match, prefer the most specific match. For example, "build broken" matches `bug:build` over `bug:functional` even though "broken" appears in both.
    74→
    75→**Default:** If no keywords match, ask the user with options:
    76→- [B] Bug (visual / functional / build / regression / data)
    77→- [F] Feature (new / enhancement / integration)
    78→- [I] Idea (exploration / design / architecture)
    79→- [V] Behavior (personality, workflow rules)
    80→- [H] Housekeeping (docs / cleanup / tooling / debt / migration)
    81→- [X] Investigation (debugging, root cause)
    82→
    83→### Area Inference from Keywords
    84→
    85→When area is not explicit, scan the input for these keywords:
    86→
    87→| Area | Keywords |
    88→|------|----------|
    89→| area:sbs:graph | "graph", "dep graph", "dependency graph", "node", "edge", "layout" |
    90→| area:sbs:dashboard | "dashboard", "stats panel", "key theorems", "project notes" |
    91→| area:sbs:paper | "paper", "ar5iv", "verification badge" |
    92→| area:sbs:pdf | "pdf", "tectonic", "pdflatex" |
    93→| area

tool_calls.input_summary: {"replace_all": false, "file_path": "/Users/eric/GitHub/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/.claude/skills/log/SKILL.md", "old_string": "## Workflow\n\n1. **Parse input** for title, body, type flags, and area flag...

input_full.old_string:
## Workflow

1. **Parse input** for title, body, type flags, and area flags
2. **Infer type** from keywords if not explicit
3. **If type unclear:** Ask user with options:
   - [B] Bug (visual / functional / build / regression / data)
   - [F] Feature (new / enhancement / integration)
   - [I] Idea (exploration / design / architecture)
   - [V] Behavior (personality, workflow rules)
   - [H] Housekeeping (docs / cleanup / tooling / debt / migration)
   - [X] Investigation (debugging, root cause)
4. **Infer area** from keywords if not explicit
5. **If title missing:** Ask "What would you like to log?"
6. **Infer conditional labels** (impact, friction, scope) from keywords
7. **Show confirmation:**

```
Creating issue:
  Title: Graph nodes overlap when cycle present
  Labels: origin:agent, bug:visual, area:sbs:graph, impact:visual

[Y] Create  [E] Edit labels  [C] Cancel
```

When user selects [E], present current labels with option to add/remove from taxonomy.

8. **Create issue** via `sbs_issue_create` MCP tool:
   - `title`: The issue title
   - `body`: Optional description with attribution footer
   - `labels`: `["origin:agent", "<type>", "<area>", ...optional impact/friction/scope...]`
9. **On success:**
   - Archive with `issue_refs` populated
   - Report issue number, URL, and labels to user
10. **On failure:**
    - Report error to user
    - Do NOT archive failed attempts
input_full.new_string:
## Workflow

### Phase 1: Alignment

Parse the user's input for initial signal, then **converse** to build shared understanding before drafting anything. This phase is user-led -- let them shape the issue.

1. **Parse input** for title, body, type flags, area flags, and initial keywords
2. **Acknowledge** what you understood from the input
3. **Probe gently** for what's missing or ambiguous:
   - If type is unclear, ask with options (see Parsing Rules)
   - If scope/context is thin, ask clarifying questions
   - If the user gave a rich description, reflect it back to confirm understanding
4. **Let the user guide.** They may want to refine scope, add context, split into multiple issues, or change direction entirely. Follow their lead.
5. **Do NOT draft the issue until alignment is achieved** -- meaning you and the user agree on what the issue should say.

**Alignment is achieved when:** You can articulate the issue clearly and the user confirms (explicitly or implicitly) that you've understood correctly. For simple, unambiguous inputs (e.g., `/log --bug sidebar broken`) alignment may be a single exchange. For vague or complex inputs, it may take several turns.

### Phase 2: Draft & Review

Once aligned, draft the complete issue and present it for approval.

6. **Infer labels** (type, area, conditional) from the aligned understanding
7. **Draft the full issue** and present it:

```
Draft issue:

  Title: Graph nodes overlap when cycle present
  Labels: origin:agent, bug:visual, area:sbs:graph, impact:visual
  Body:
    When the dependency graph contains a cycle, nodes overlap
    and edges cross through unrelated nodes. Reproducible on
    SBS-Test with the cyclic-deps test case.

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel
```

When user selects [E], allow editing title, body, or labels. For label edits, present current labels with option to add/remove from taxonomy.

### Phase 3: Create

8. **Create issue** via `sbs_issue_create` MCP tool:
   - `title`: The issue title
   - `body`: Description with attribution footer
   - `labels`: `["origin:agent", "<type>", "<area>", ...optional impact/friction/scope...]`
9. **On success:**
   - Archive with `issue_refs` populated
   - Report issue number, URL, and labels to user
10. **On failure:**
    - Report error to user
    - Do NOT archive failed attempts

### Closing Discipline

**Do not aggressively seek to close issues.** The `/log` skill captures issues -- it does not resolve them. After creating an issue:
- Report it and move on
- Do not suggest immediate fixes or offer to resolve unless the user asks
- Do not tie the issue to a `/task` invocation unless the user initiates that connection
- The issue exists to be tracked, not to be closed in the same breath it was opened

input_full.new_string:
### Fully Interactive (alignment takes multiple turns)

```
User: /log

Claude: What's on your mind?

User: The sidebar doesn't highlight the active section

Claude: Got it -- so when you're viewing a chapter page, the sidebar entry
        for that chapter doesn't visually indicate it's the current one?
        Is this in both light and dark themes, or just one?

User: Both themes. It used to work but I think the CSS refactor broke it.

Claude: That sounds like a regression from the CSS variable migration.

Draft issue:

  Title: Sidebar doesn't highlight active section after CSS refactor
  Labels: origin:agent, bug:regression, area:sbs:sidebar, area:sbs:css, impact:visual
  Body:
    The sidebar navigation no longer highlights the currently active
    chapter/section. Affects both light and dark themes. Likely
    regressed during the CSS variable refactor.

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel

User: Y

Claude: Created issue #42: "Sidebar doesn't highlight active section after CSS refactor"
        Labels: origin:agent, bug:regression, area:sbs:sidebar, area:sbs:css, impact:visual
        https://github.com/e-vergo/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/issues/42
```

### Quick Alignment (clear input, minimal exchange)

```
User: /log graph nodes look wrong in dark mode

Claude: Nodes look wrong how -- color, shape, overlap, or something else?

User: The colors don't adapt, they stay the same as light mode

Claude: Draft issue:

  Title: Graph node colors don't adapt to dark mode
  Labels: origin:agent, bug:visual, area:sbs:graph, area:sbs:theme, impact:visual
  Body:
    Graph node colors remain unchanged in dark mode -- they use
    the light mode palette instead of adapting to the dark theme.

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel

User: Y

Claude: Created issue #43: https://github.com/...
```

### Explicit Type (alignment still happens)

```
User: /log --feature add dark mode toggle to paper view

Claude: The paper view currently inherits the global theme. You're saying it
        should have its own independent toggle? Or is this about the global
        toggle not being visible/accessible from the paper view?

User: The global toggle isn't visible from the paper view

Claude: Draft issue:

  Title: Make theme toggle accessible from paper view
  Labels: origin:agent, feature:enhancement, area:sbs:paper, area:sbs:theme
  Body:
    The global theme toggle is not visible when viewing the paper page.
    Users have to navigate away to change themes. The toggle should be
    accessible from the paper view.

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel

User: Y

Claude: Created issue #44: "Make theme toggle accessible from paper view"
        https://github.com/...
```

### Edit Flow

```
User: /log slow build times are painful

Claude: Which part of the build is the bottleneck? Lake build, artifact
        generation, site generation, or the full pipeline end-to-end?

User: The full pipeline. PNT takes 20 minutes and I can't iterate.

Claude: Draft issue:

  Title: Full build pipeline too slow for iterative development
  Labels: origin:agent, investigation, impact:performance, friction:slow-feedback
  Body:
    The end-to-end build pipeline (Lake -> Dress -> Runway) blocks
    iterative development. PNT takes ~20 minutes. Need to investigate
    where time is spent and whether incremental builds can help.

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel

User: E -- change type to feature:enhancement and add scope:architectural

Claude: Updated draft:

  Title: Full build pipeline too slow for iterative development
  Labels: origin:agent, feature:enhancement, impact:performance,
          friction:slow-feedback, scope:architectural
  Body: (unchanged)

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel

User: Y

Claude: Created issue #46: "Full build pipeline too slow for iterative development"
        https://github.com/...
```

### Full Specification (minimal alignment needed)

```
User: /log --idea --body "Could show node metadata on hover instead of requiring click" tooltips for graph nodes

Claude: Clear -- hover tooltips instead of click-to-open for graph node metadata.
        Anything else to add, or does this capture it?

User: That's it

Claude: Draft issue:

  Title: Tooltips for graph nodes
  Labels: origin:agent, idea:design, area:sbs:graph, area:sbs:tooltips
  Body:
    Could show node metadata on hover instead of requiring click.
    Would make graph exploration faster and more discoverable.

[Y] Create  [E] Edit  [C] Cancel

User: Y

Claude: Created idea issue #45: "Tooltips for graph nodes"
        https://github.com/...
```

version: 3.0.0
---

# /log - Issue Capture with Alignment

Capture bugs, features, and ideas as GitHub issues through conversational alignment. Understands the issue through dialogue before drafting, then presents the full issue for review. Applies multi-dimensional labels from the project taxonomy for rich categorization.

tool_calls.input_summary: {"title": "Add testing/gating parity for /log v3.0 alignment workflow", "body": "The `/log` skill was updated to v3.0 with an alignment phase mirroring `/task`'s structure (alignment \u2192 draft & re...

input_full.title: Add testing/gating parity for /log v3.0 alignment workflow
input_full.body:
The `/log` skill was updated to v3.0 with an alignment phase mirroring `/task`'s structure (alignment → draft & review → create). This new workflow needs test and gate coverage at parity with `/task`:

- **Behavioral pytest tests** verifying the three-phase workflow (alignment, draft & review, create) executes correctly
- **Integration with the evergreen gating system** so skill transitions are blocked on test failure
- **Archive entry validation** confirming `issue_refs`, `trigger`, and labels are correctly recorded

Reference: `/task` gating uses `pytest -m evergreen --tb=short` with 100% pass rate required for phase transitions.

---
Created with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)
